Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit in judgement on murders - "crossing red light", eh?

You patrol your own streets. You travel 60 km/hour. We don't.

If you wish to judge murder, without first having gone over every point with cops or detectives

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to this hybrid England/Australian production.
But there's a strange aftertaste - dullness in places where you'd expect action and emotion to flow readily. Parts of Marian Bracewell's script balance on laughable archaic speech and occasionally feel stilted or manipulative.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to catch the wave of martial arts popularity ; It borrows many characteristics of other (beginning to hit its peak) films and tries too hard to appear modern with trendy music, but also a generic script with low production value .
